title: Choosing Yarn for Machine Knitting: What Works and What Doesn't
author: Sue Jalowiec
excerpt: Not all yarns are created equal when it comes to machine knitting. Learn which characteristics to look for and which to avoid.
description: Not all yarns are created equal when it comes to machine knitting. Learn which characteristics to look for and which to avoid.
body:
One of the most common questions I hear from new machine knitters is: "Can I use this yarn on my machine?" The answer isn't always straightforward, but understanding yarn characteristics will help you make better choices.

The Golden Rule

If you can't see the individual plies and the yarn feels smooth and consistent, it's probably machine-friendly. If it's fuzzy, lumpy, or heavily textured, proceed with caution—or skip it entirely.

Yarn Characteristics That Work Well

1. Smooth Plied Yarns

Machine knitting needles have hooks and latches that need to grab and release yarn cleanly. Smooth yarns with visible plies work beautifully because they:

  • Slide through the carriage and tension mast smoothly
  • Don't catch on needle latches
  • Create even, consistent fabric

Examples: Wool blends, cotton, silk, bamboo, acrylic (smooth finish)

2. Consistent Weight

Yarns with consistent thickness knit evenly. Irregularities cause tension issues and can jam your carriage.

3. Moderate Twist

Too little twist and the yarn falls apart. Too much twist and it's hard to work with. Look for yarns with a balanced, medium twist.

Yarns to Avoid (or Use with Caution)

❌ Fuzzy or Hairy Yarns

Mohair, angora, alpaca, and heavily brushed yarns catch on everything. The fibers get stuck in needle latches, jam the carriage, and create frustrating tangles.

Exception: You can sometimes use these yarns held together with a smooth carrier yarn, though this requires advanced technique.

❌ Thick-and-Thin "Art" Yarns

Novelty yarns with intentional slubs, thick sections, and thin sections don't work well on standard or fine gauge machines. The thick parts won't fit through the needles, and the thin parts won't create proper stitches.

❌ Loosely Spun Singles

Single-ply roving-style yarns tend to break under tension and pull apart during knitting. Stick with 2-ply or more.

❌ Stretchy Elastic Yarns

Yarns with built-in elastic (some sock yarns) can cause tension nightmares. They stretch as they knit and then spring back, creating uneven fabric.

Yarn Weight Guide

Machine Type Recommended Yarn Weight Common Names
Standard Gauge Sport to DK Light worsted, DK, sport weight
Mid Gauge DK to Worsted Worsted, aran, heavy DK
Bulky/Chunky Worsted to Bulky Chunky, bulky, heavy worsted

Testing New Yarn

Before committing to a full project, always test:

  1. Wind a small cone or ball and thread it through your machine
  2. Knit a 20-stitch, 20-row swatch at your planned tension
  3. Watch for problems: Yarn breakage, needle catching, uneven stitches
  4. Evaluate the fabric: Does it look and feel how you want?

Where to Buy Machine Knitting Yarn

Many yarn suppliers sell on cones specifically for machine knitting. These are often:

  • More economical than hand-knitting yarn
  • Pre-tested for machine compatibility
  • Available in consistent dye lots
  • Wound for proper tension feeding
Pro tip: Save yarn labels and bands from yarns that work well for you. Note the fiber content, weight, and how it performed. You'll build a reference library of trusted yarns.

Final Thoughts

While machine knitting does limit your yarn choices compared to hand knitting, you still have thousands of beautiful options. Focus on yarns designed for machines or with machine-friendly characteristics, and you'll save yourself hours of frustration.

Happy knitting!
